content.description: One of the better routes at Mentmore, this climb starts with a crux on SMALL, sharp holds, then follows a system of flakes to the top (fun!), finishing up with a nice little roof.  The flakes feel reasonably solid.  The start is by FAR the hardest part (and harder for shorter people), but if you can reach the first bolt, it's easy to pull through on a draw.  Probably more like 5.10b if you pull through the lowest section.
content.location: Just right of the obvious offwidth crack in the corner (Fetus Envy).  Lower or walk off; could be hard to pull the rope after rapping.

content.description: A fun but reachy line on the varnished wall right of Joe's Crack.  The bulge near the 2nd bolt is probably the crux for most people.  One of the more popular lines at Mentmore.
content.location: Look for the generally left-trending bolt line right next to the chiseled "Benny Silva" graffito.  The first bolt line left of the "Big Blobs of Love" arete.  Walk off, lower, or rap.

content.description: A fun route with a great start.  Pull a few moves on small crimps (5.11b if taller, 5.11c if shorter) to a substantial and obvious clipping hold, then another few great moves to the obvious lip (don't forget to use the bullet holes!).  Pull the roof above (strenuous but good holds), and then cruise the lower-angled terrain above.  This route shares the last two bolts and the anchor with Rapture.  Recommended for the bottom 20 feet alone.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a 2-anchor.  The boltline trends right to the anchor, so if you're planning on TRing, you probably want a directional on the third bolt.
content.location: The first boltline right of the prominent handcrack (Joe's Crack).

content.description: One of the nicer cracks at Mentmore.  This can be climbed almost entirely as a face climb, but it'll be a lot easier and more enjoyable (esp. the bottom) if you have basic hand-jamming skills.  Can be toproped, but the crack traverses generally left, so you might want to put in a directional piece if toproping with inexperienced climbers.  Finally, WATCH OUT for a large whitish block jammed in the very top of the crack.  It seems pretty solidly wedged, but you never know...
content.protection: Trad gear all the way.  Crack pinches down as it goes higher, so a few cams from 1-3 inches oughta do ya.  There is a bolted anchor at the top.
content.location: Obvious handcrack splitting the Benny Silva Wall.

content.description: Offwidth crack with a small roof about 1/3 of the way up.  Pull the roof on decent face holds, then jam or lieback the crack as the angle eases.  Top is a bit loose, but easy.  Just don't kick rocks down on your belayer.  A fun climb that can be done with little to no jamming technique.  So-so rock quality.
content.protection: Trad gear all the way to the top.  It's wide, so bring the big cams.  #4 Friend is the smallest piece you'll be able to use till high up on the route.  There is no anchor at the top, but it's easy to build one with 1.0-1.5 inch pieces.
content.location: The obvious wide crack in a corner at the left end of the Benny Silva Wall.  Walk off.

content.description: A fun sport climb that climbs a juggy arete.  The start can be hard, especially for shorter or less-experienced climbers.  If struggling higher on the route, remember to use both side of the arete.  Not a bad choice for a first lead: well-protected, and with generally good clipping stances.
content.location: The route follows the prominent arete the separates Health Wall from Benny Silva Wall.   Walk off or rap.  Try to avoid lowering off and leaving slings on the anchors: retrieving them from above might be a little frightening.

content.description: This wall is adjacent to the Health Wall, and separated from it by a prominent arete.  Look for Joe's Crack, a prominent handcrack that splits the wall and is clearly visible from a distance.  If in doubt, look for the "benny silva" graffito chiseled into the rock at eye level.
